abstract_problem: A drought-stricken region is constructing water supply pipelines to transport water from a water source to various villages. There are a total of {num_nodes} water transport nodes, with IDs from 1 to {num_nodes}. Only the node with ID {source_node} is the water source, with a total supply of {total_supply}, while other nodes are demand points. The supply or demand quantities are specified in `nodes`, where positive values indicate supply, negative values indicate demand, and 0 indicates that the node itself does not require water supply but can serve as a transit point as needed. Each pipeline has a fixed construction cost and a variable cost per unit of flow, see `edges`. The network must form a tree structure (each node has at most one incoming edge). The objective is to minimize the total cost (construction cost + flow cost).

nodes.description:
A table with columns `id` and `value`. `value` represents the net supply (positive) or demand (negative) of the node.
Data format:
| id | value |
| --- | --- |
| 1 | 384.0 |
| 2 | -2.0 |
| ... | ... |

edges.description:
A table with columns `id1`, `id2`, `fixed_cost`, `variable_cost`. `id1` <= `id2`. Represents potential pipelines with bidirectional flow costs.
Data format:
| id1 | id2 | fixed_cost | variable_cost |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | 2 | 50.0 | 1.0 |
| 1 | 3 | 254.950976 | 5.09902 |
| ... | ... | ... | ... |
